I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The clean development mechanism (CDM) was proposed under the Kyoto Protocol to 
reduce global emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) and to assist developing countries in 
achieving sustainable development. During the Country Programming Mission of 2002, the 
Government of Indonesia requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to include in the 
Country Strategy and Program (CSP) 2003–2005 technical assistance (TA) for institutional 
development to manage and promote CDM. ADB fielded the Fact-Finding Mission during 23-30 
August 2004 to prepare the TA paper on Institutionalizing the Clean Development Mechanism.1 
The Mission held discussions with officials from the BAPPENAS (National Development and 
Planning Agency), Ministry of Environment, Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, and 
other relevant government agencies regarding the TA on CDM, and solicited the Government’s 
views on the TA objectives, scope, terms of reference, implementation arrangements and cost 
estimates. The Mission and the Government reached an understanding on the TA goals, scope, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference.2  The TA 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Indonesia was one of the fastest growing economies in Southeast Asia before the 
financial crisis in 1997. It has stabilized and has had growth rates ranging from 3.4% to 4.9% 
since 2000. Indonesia has significant deposits of coal, oil and gas and its future economic 
growth will increase the domestic demand for these energy sources and lead to an increase in 
GHG emissions. The Asia Least-Cost Greenhouse Gas Abatement Strategy (ALGAS) study3 
estimated that energy sector emissions for Indonesia would increase from 125.30 million tons 
carbon dioxide equivalent in 1990 to 541.13 million tons in 2010 and 913.13 million tons in 
2020. Developing member countries’ (DMC) participation in the global effort to reduce GHG 
emissions is constrained due to their concerns that this would slow down their economic 
growth. The CDM is a cooperative instrument that will enable DMCs to participate in GHG 
emissions reduction (ER) and simultaneously attain sustainable development. 
 
3.  In June 1992 with the ratification of the United Nations Framework Convention on 
Climate Change (UNFCCC), a likely change in climate was accepted as a global environmental 
challenge. Stabilization of GHG emissions was the most important objective of the convention. 
At the third conference of the parties to the UNFCCC (COP-3) in 1997, the Kyoto Protocol to 
UNFCCC was adopted where the developed countries agreed to reduce their overall emissions 
by 5.2% below 1990 levels in the first commitment period of 2008–2012. CDM, a market-based 
mechanism, introduced under the Kyoto Protocol, enables developed countries (or Annex I 
parties) to meet their ER commitments in a flexible and cost-effective manner and assists 
developing countries in meeting their sustainable development objectives. While developed 
countries benefit by obtaining GHG ER credits at a lower cost than in their own economies, the 
gains to the host countries are investments that lead to local sustainable development benefits.  
 
4.  At the COP-7 to the UNFCCC held in Marrakesh, Morocco, in November 2001, the 
basic rules for the CDM were agreed upon. Projects starting in 2000 are eligible to earn credits 
for ER if they lead to “real, measurable, and long-term” GHG reductions, which are additional to 
any  that  would  occur  in  the  absence  of  the  CDM  project. A  CDM  executive  board  was

established with 20 members, and was authorized to approve methodologies for CDM projects,

5.  A CDM project produces a new commodity, ER credits, or avoided emissions. CDM 
project processing requires development of the project design document (PDD), validation of 
the  PDD  by  an  independent  entity4,  registration  of  the  project  with  the  executive  board, 
monitoring and verification of ERs during project operation, and certification of the ERs by the 
executive board. Certified ERs can be traded to generate revenue for the project owner and 
can be used by Annex I parties to meet their GHG reduction obligations.  
 
6.  CDM  projects  generate  ER  credits  through  initiatives  that  include  promotion  of 
renewable energy, methane gas capture, industrial efficiency improvements, fuel switching, 
demand-side efficiency improvements, and forestry and agriculture sector initiatives. These 
projects embody win-win results like GHG abatement while reducing domestic demand for fossil 
fuels and other environmental pollutants. Indonesia has a large potential to benefit from such 
win-win options. However, as CDM is a new instrument, capacity development is required 
among the potential CDM developers and the government to process CDM projects. Lack of 
proper institutions can impede the efficient implementation of CDM projects.  
 
7.  The Kyoto Protocol will become effective in February 2005.5 Many developed countries 
have initiated national plans to meet their Kyoto targets. Indonesia signed the Kyoto Protocol in 
July  1998  and  established  a  National  Committee  on  Climate  Change.    The  Indonesian 
Government and Parliament approved law number 17/2004 to ratify the Kyoto Protocol on 23 
June 2004. CDM approval procedures are being formulated and urgent action is required to 
establish the necessary institutions for implementing CDM projects. This process needs internal 
support from various government agencies. However, the capacity in different agencies to 
understand the CDM process hinders the expeditious implementation of CDM. 
 
8.  Indonesia has a strong commitment to the millennium development goals (MDGs) and 
BAPPENAS has the lead role in incorporating them in the Five-Year National Development 
Plan.  CDM  contributes  to  goal  7,  which  is  to  ensure  environmental  sustainability,  and 
specifically to target 9, which is to integrate principles of sustainable development into country 
policies and programs and reverse the loss of environmental resources. One of the indicators 
for target 9 is per capita emission of carbon dioxide equivalent. CDM projects will help lower per 
capita carbon emissions, taking Indonesia closer to achieving its MDGs. 
 
9.  ADB has earlier supported capacity building TAs on GHG mitigation. The ALGAS project 
(footnote  3)  was  developed  through  a  regional TA6  for  12  DMCs  (including  Indonesia)  to 
develop their first GHG inventory. Other ADB TAs for GHG reduction include the PREGA 
(Promotion  of  Renewable  Energy  and  Energy  Efficiency  for  Greenhouse  Gas Abatement) 
project,  which  aims  to  promote  investments  in  renewable  energy  and  energy  efficiency 
technologies  that  will  help  reduce  GHG  emissions.7    A  TA  on  carbon  sequestration8  was

revenues. ADB has also established the CDM Facility to facilitate agreements between buyers

10.  The 2003–2005 CSP and CSP Update 2004–2006 address the main medium-term 
needs of the economy, stressing (i) improvements in governance, (ii) meeting local needs 
through  decentralization,  (iii)  human  development,  (iv)  environmental  management  and 
sustainable use of natural resources, and (v) raising long-term growth prospects and economic 
potential. This TA contributes to (iv) by developing capacity to implement CDM projects, like 
renewable energy projects, energy efficiency improvements in industries, and improved waste 
management practices. Such initiatives will increase the access of remote and rural populations 
to  efficient  and  modern  forms  of  energy  through  the  proliferation  of  renewable  energy 
applications,  conserve  fossil  fuels,  and  allow  environmentally  sustainable  practices  in 
agriculture and industry. The potential for GHG abatement projects is large and developing 
them as CDM projects will help achieve both local and global objectives.  
 
11.  The Government has established an inter-ministerial working group that participates in 
the ongoing international deliberations. An Indonesian independent power producer is trading 
carbon credits from its geothermal power plant. The Government is negotiating bilateral carbon 
purchase agreements. This TA will strengthen the Government’s capacity to process CDM 
projects and to negotiate with international parties more efficiently, increase the acceptability of 
CDM  projects  by  local  and  national  agencies,  enhance  local  capacity  in  preparing  CDM 
projects, and lower transactions costs. For investors and buyers this will reduce uncertainty, 
improve  reliability  and  ensure  efficient  production  and  procurement  of  ER  credits.  Waste 
management has a large potential for generating carbon credits and would address a growing 
problem in urban areas. In Indonesia, so far CDM strategies exist only for the energy sector, 
thereby necessitating a CDM policy for waste management.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The  goal  of  the  TA  is  to  achieve  lower  GHG  emissions  and  support  sustainable 
development.  The  purpose  of  the  TA  is  to  maximize  benefits  from  CDM  and  to  develop 
institutional capacity to process/promote CDM projects. The TA will (i) develop capacity for and 
increase awareness about the CDM process and its potential as a source of financing among 
local government, commercial banking sectors, and financial and other relevant public and 
government  institutions;  (ii)  develop  the  capacity  of  local  trainers  to  guide  consultants  in 
developing CDM projects, specially for small-scale activities; (iii) assist potential local applicants 
to  become  designated  operational  entities  (DOEs);  (iv)  formulate  policy  and  strategy  for 
developing CDM in the waste management sector; (v) facilitate collaboration on CDM between 
the government and industries; (vi) develop good practice examples of CDM including project 
design,  validation,  registration,  financing  and  impact  assessment  for  at  least  three  CDM 
projects; (vii) assist the Government in developing national CDM guidelines and internal CDM 
procedures in Bahasa Indonesia; and (viii) disseminate the TA findings to stakeholders.  
 
13.  The deliverables from the TA include (i) a review of the CDM process and its potential 
to  finance  projects  in  Indonesia;  (ii)  at  least  five  regional  training  workshops  for  local 
government officials, and local commercial bank staff on issues and requirements of CDM 
project activities; (iii) two CDM awareness building workshops for national public institutions, 
including the Ministry of Finance, BAPPENAS, and state auditors; (iv) guidelines elaborating

4 
simplified small-scale CDM modalities and procedures; (v) training workshops for building the 
capacity of local trainers to train national consultants in developing small-scale CDM projects; 
(vi) sector policy and strategy outline to promote CDM activities in waste management projects; 
(vii) roundtable discussions between representatives of industry, designated national authority 
(DNA) and international experts on problems faced in developing CDM projects; (viii) support to 
potential local DOEs to register; (ix) at least three draft PDDs for CDM; (x) validation and 
registration of the PDDs produced in (ix); and (xi) national guidelines and procedures on CDM 
processing  and  implementation  including  ER  purchase  agreements,  monitoring,  and 
certification process. The focus will be on, but not restricted to, small-scale CDM projects. The 
training programs material, reference manuals, and guidelines will be developed in English and 
Bahasa Indonesia.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
14.  The first task of the TA is to provide analytical information to various parties involved 
with the development of CDM projects. The TA will conduct awareness and capacity building 
participatory  workshops  and  seminars,  provide  documentation  in  the  local  language,  and 
provide support in incorporating CDM projects in an institution’s activities. For example, the TA 
will explain to local commercial banks how CDM can affect the project’s rate of return, and the 
uncertainties associated with the CDM, to facilitate the processing of projects with a CDM 
component. The TA will train trainers who, in turn, will guide national consultants on CDM 
project activities. Guidelines elaborating simplified small-scale modalities, manuals and case 
studies will be developed to assist national consultants and project developers. The executing 
agency (EA) and implementing agencies (IAs) with assistance from the TA consultants, will 
identify local entities to be trained as trainers. Hands-on training will be given to the trainers by 
involving them in developing examples of CDM projects and in providing inputs to the regional 
workshops. The TA will also guide local entities that may want to register as DOEs.  
 
15.  The TA will develop a strategy for promoting CDM in the waste management sector.  
The strategy will include an assessment of the CDM potential in the sector, and policies and 
strategies required to optimize global and local benefits. Approved CDM methodologies for 
landfill gas will be considered in developing the country strategy for waste management. The 
Government  will  be  consulted  in  evaluating  different  policy  options  and  institutional 
requirements. The consultants will also identify other sectors where similar strategies can be 
developed. 
 
16.  The TA will develop at least three CDM projects as good practice examples based on 
real data. The projects will highlight the role of local, provincial, and national institutions in the 
CDM process. Gaps identified in institutional capacity will be addressed under the TA. These 
projects will be in addition to cases developed under the waste management strategy and will 
not include carbon sequestration, which is included in the ongoing ADB TA 4137-INO (see 
footnote 8). The TA will produce the CDM guidelines in Bahasa Indonesia for internal purposes, 
and a draft of procedures on government-to-government CDM processes, which is secure, in 
line with regulations, simple, and non-bureaucratic. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $938,000 equivalent, comprising $510,000 in 
foreign  exchange  and  $428,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  ADB  will  provide  $750,000 
equivalent to finance the entire foreign exchange cost and $240,000 equivalent of the local 
currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program.  The

5 
Government will finance the remaining $188,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
  
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  As EA, the Directorate of Environment and Natural Resources of BAPPENAS will have 
overall  responsibility  for  TA  management  and  implementation.  Two  IAs—the  Ministry  of 
Environment,  and  DGEEU  of  the  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Mineral  Resources  have  been 
identified. Additional IAs, if required, can be identified during TA implementation. A steering 
committee will be set up to review and advise on TA implementation. The committee, to be 
chaired by BAPPENAS, will include representatives from the Ministry of Environment, Ministry 
of Agriculture, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Public Works, Ministry 
of  State-Owned  Enterprises,  Ministry  of  Energy  and  Mineral  Resources,  Ministry  of  Home 
Affairs, CDM DNA, research institutes, universities, and representatives of local governments 
and commercial financial institutions. The IAs will assist the EA in identifying areas to focus on, 
be stakeholders for different components, and participate in and provide inputs for the training 
process and the three potential CDM projects. All decision-making processes will be guided by 
the steering committee, including approval of TA outputs before their submission to ADB. The 
EA and the IAs will cover their respective budgets. 
 
19.  The TA will be carried out in 15 months, from March 2005 to May 2006. A consulting 
firm with expertise in CDM project development, policy analysis, economic analysis, capacity 
building and waste management will be engaged to undertake the major TA components. The 
consulting firm will provide an international expert in CDM and financial and economic analyses 
who will be the team leader, an international legal expert, an international waste management 
expert, and five domestic consultants. The domestic consultants will have expertise in CDM 
and financial sector, renewable energy, waste management, and social and institutional issues. 
Total  consulting  services  to  be  provided  by  the  firm  will  include  12  person-months  of 
international expertise and 22 person-months of domestic expertise. The consultants’ terms of 
reference are in Appendix 3. Domestic resource persons will also be engaged separately for 
approximately 4 person-months. All consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging 
domestic consultants. Simplified technical proposals will be evaluated using the quality- and 
cost-based selection method for the consulting firm. The consultants will work closely with the 
EA  and  the  IAs.  Equipment  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for 
Procurement,  and  retained  by  the  EA  upon  TA  completion.  The  TA  findings  will  be 
disseminated among concerned stakeholders through workshops and seminars. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Indonesia for Institutionalizing the Clean Development Mechanism Project, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction  
1.  The clean development mechanism (CDM) as defined in the Kyoto Protocol and in the 
Marrakech Accords of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) is 
an  instrument  that  delivers  local  and  global  benefits.  CDM  can  assist  Indonesia  to  reduce 
dependence  on  fossil  fuel  by  developing  and  using  indigenous  new  and  renewable  energy 
resources as mandated in its national energy policy. A strategy for improved waste management 
systems not only reduces emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) but also provides effective ways 
to manage waste. The optimal use of CDM requires building the capacity of government agencies 
and the private sector to develop and process CDM projects, especially small-scale projects. To 
meet the objectives set in this technical assistance (TA) document and to deliver the outputs listed 
in Section C of this Appendix, the terms of reference for the consulting team are presented in 
Section B. The Directorate of Environment and Natural Resources of BAPPENAS will be the 
Executing Agency with the Directorate General of Electricity and Energy Utilization (DGEEU) of the 
Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources, and the Ministry of Environment as implementing 
agencies (IAs). Consulting services comprising 12 person-months international and 22 person-
months domestic inputs are envisaged, intermittently for specific consultants. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference  
 
2.  The consultants will work as a team to carry out various tasks, including, but not limited to 
the following. The international CDM expert will be the team leader. 
 
1.  International CDM Expert/Team Leader 
3.  The tasks of the CDM expert include the following:  
(i)  Assess the feasibility of implementing CDM policies, rules, and regulations within existing 
institutional responsibilities, mechanisms, and resources. 
(ii)  Coordinate  and  organize  awareness  and  capacity-building  participatory  workshops, 
focusing  on  national  and  local  institutions  and  agencies,  in  both  public  and  private 
sectors.  
(iii)  Use guidelines, manuals, and case studies elaborating CDM modalities to train national 
consultants and project developers to develop CDM projects.  
(iv)  Assist potential local operational entities to register as designated operational entities 
(DOEs) and to function as validating and verifying agencies. 
(v)  Prepare a framework for promoting CDM projects, with special attention to small-scale 
projects. Use the information generated in (i) to develop a strategy to overcome market 
and nonmarket barriers to the development and promotion of CDM projects. Provide a set 
of  sample  CDM  project  outlines  for  various  stakeholders  including  the  government, 
industry, and financial institutions. 
(vi)  Identify five regions whose capacity can be developed at the local level, based on the 
potential  for  CDM,  sector  and  size,  technical  aspects,  funding  needs,  location,  and 
potential for dissemination as good practice. Apply these criteria to select investment

C.  Deliverable Outputs 
12.  The deliverables from the TA include, but are not limited to, (i) a review of the CDM process 
and its potential to finance projects in Indonesia; (ii) policies and strategies to promote CDM 
projects; (iii) at least five regional training workshops for local government officials and commercial 
bank staff on issues and requirements of CDM; (iv) at least two workshops for awareness building 
on  CDM  in  national  public  institutions,  including  the  Ministry  of  Finance,  BAPPENAS,  state 
auditors; (v) guidelines elaborating simplified small-scale CDM modalities and procedures; (vi) 3-4 
training workshops to building the capacity of local trainers to train national consultants to develop 
of small-scale CDM projects; (vii) policy and strategy outlines to promote CDM projects in waste 
management; (viii) roundtable discussions between industry, DNA, and consultants on problems 
faced in developing CDM projects; (ix) support and guidance to potential local DOEs; (x) at least 
three project design documents for CDM that will be validated and registered; (xi) a summary of 
government  views  on  each  of  the  project  design  documents;  (xii)  national  guidelines  and 
procedures  on  CDM  processing  and  implementation,  including  monitoring  and  a  certification 
process for small-scale and bundled CDM projects; (xiii) model ER purchase agreements for 
different project types; and (xiv) an action plan and policy that may help international financing 
organizations such as ADB to further pursue dialogue on the proposed projects. The training 
programs material, reference manuals, and guidelines will be developed in English and Bahasa 
Indonesia. The consultants will deliver an inception report, 1 month after the start of the TA; an 
interim report, 6 months after the inception report; a draft final report, 13.5 months after the TA 
starts; and the final report at the end of the TA.
